header.title: Anti-LGBT protesters meet resistance after returning to Birmingham school
header.postText: Anti-LGBT protesters were drowned out by a ‘loving resistance’ musical counter-protest when they returned to a Birmingham school.', 'Around 20 campaigners demonstrated near Anderton Park School, in Sparkhill, yesterday.', 'They were complaining about lessons where pupils learn about gay relationships and LGBT rights.', 'But this time they were met with resistance from gay mother Katy Rose Bennett, a local resident, and her friends who sang defiant songs of love, including A Beautiful World and Over the Rainbow.', 'Musician Ms Bennett said she decided to act after having to put up with protests at the school gates since January.', 'She said: ‘We believe in love and harmony and everyone getting along and being equal. Love conquers hate.’', 'Resident Philip Coker added: ‘Their children are the future, but they just do not want them to have a future that is different from theirs.', '‘They are giving their children a terrible message.’', 'Lead protester Mr Afsar said they returned because he didn’t want the school to think they had gone away.', 'He said: ‘We will not back down. Parents want us to continue to press for the school to heed their request, consult with parents and stop going against their wishes.’', 'Fellow protester Amir Ahmed added: ‘They say this is about equality and tolerance. There are other ways to teach equality – this is a sexual and gender ideology.’', 'Birmingham City Council will again request a permanent injunction around the school to ban protests at the gates when it goes to court on October 14.', 'A temporary injunction, imposed in June, bans Mr Afsar and other protest leaders from organising a demonstration or abusing school employees inside an exclusion zone.', 'Anderton Park School was targeted along with Parkfield School in Alum Rock.', 'Anti-LGBT protesters started their demonstrations in March.
header.socioLingVar: Sexual Identity - General,Sexual Identity - Male homosexuality,Sexual Identity - Transexuality,Gender - General,Age - General

Martina Zelenić Dove "Why do you think that your religious beliefs, or anyone's religious beliefs carry more weight than other people's rights that are protected by law?" Because laws are someone's beliefs, religious or otherwise, enshrined in police enforced codex. So your question is logically fallacious. What you really asked is: why do you think that your/anyone's religious beliefs carry more weight than other people's beliefs. And the answer is that noone's beliefs carry more weight. So be careful of logic.

Anne Cullagh Children tend to be very accepting of diversity. No one is teaching them about the ins and outs of sexual intercourse, just that sometimes men love men, women love women and some children have two parents of the same sex. The problem is that children are taught discrimination from a youn g age by their families and schools can at least provide an alternative, more socially acceptable, counteracting viewpoint. Take a look at the picture above of those women with their heads and faces covered. My mother used to teach in a nursery school where the majority of children were Muslim. One girl asked her how she got to work and when she said she drove herself the girls thought it was strange and funny that she would. These were four ye ar old girls who'd already been tought as part of Muslim upbringing that women shouldn't be going out on their own and driving themselves to places because they had to have the supervision of men. I worry about children being pushed down the road of believing they 're transgender and using puberty blocking drugs. I do think children should be allowed to be whoever they feel they are without concern for whether their physical bodies and feelings fit gender stereotypes. However, the problem here is clearly those who choose to follow a religion objecti ng to sexual orientations, that aren't a choice, being portrayed as an acceptable part of life and something that should be respected. They want to teach their children that homosexuality is wrong and lead new generations down the path of intolerance and hate. That's something modern education has a responsibility to fight against.

Im not talking from a muslims point of view im talking from a British one who did not push religion or politics on to kids which is pointless anyway seeing as they learn everything from social media which is something no one can escape from ,so i dont no were all this hate is coming from in the first place but the point im trying to make is that its really a parents job to teach children how to behave and respect people its a credit to a parent that a child does well with others and is well loved ,handing over the responsibility to primary school teacher who have enough to deal with in the first place is wrong if there is a negative attitude at home then its not gona stop anything its just going to cause unbelievable unhappiness for a child being taught one thing at school and another at home this issue is sensitive and should be treated as such being forced to accept something will never work to be honest all this is very much saying your a bad parent and we know better well i can tell you from my very own experiences the  worst bullies in my childrens primary school were politically correct teacher's (not all ) im very sorry if some people had a horrible time in primary school that is just awful

commentThread.commentText: Fellow protester Amir Ahmed added: ‘They say this is about equality and tolerance. There are other ways to teach equality – this is a sexual and gender ideology.’Amir, that could also be said about religion and we teach tolerance about that too. Maybe your religious beliefs clash wit h L GB< /b>>T rights and that's OK. Why? Because the law is there to ensure that everyone has equal rights. If you don't mind other people's children being taught to be tolerant of your religious belief s or gender rights, then you should be smart enough to see that this also goes the other way. As a parent, you also should want to raise a child that can easily adapt to the society it is living in no matter what they believe and knowing the laws and social expectations of that society is a good start.

replies.commentText: LGBT *is* a religion to all practical intents and purposes.  That is to say, it is a belief system with doctrines that are ethical, metaphysical, mythical and suchlike, which contradict doctrines that are readily recognised as religious in character, and which not everybody believes, and which many people find utterly incredible and even morally repulsive and not age-appropriate for little children.

commentThread.commentText: It's not just about LGB T.< /b>> No outsiders is about validating different kinds of families. A child may have 2 mummies or 2 daddies because they are fostered, adopted, being brought up by grandparents, parents remarried, conceived by donor or surrogacy or their parents a re g>ay. They may have a single parent. This maybe none of the school's business but even at junior school as simple history lesson might begin with asking for a family tree. The kids are going to ask questions and the teachers have to be able to answer them. Children from single parent households have been primed to fail for many decades in our school system. Yet we now know that children of single parents can do very well in life. That is what school is for. Religious people thrive on making nasty little distinctions between people and setting kids up for failure, which is precisely why their point of view is inappropriate for schools.
Funny how so many consider not being allowed to hate to be discrimination against their mythology.

I was there. The little huddle of LGBT-ist counter-demonstrators didn't "drown" the sound of the parent empowerment demonstrators whom they accused of "hate" rather than their so-called "love" presumably.There were no reporters there from the Metro. If there had been, they'd have interviewed me, my having juist got added to the court case an hour or so beforehand. The Metro has just made up a story, based upon what it has heard, which is thin on facts and heavy on spin and, by no stretch of the imagination, balanced.
